standards.parent_tip: Ask your child to support their answers with evidence: 'What in the story makes you think that?'

questions.prompt:
Elena clutched her telescope and crept onto the rooftop. The city lights dimmed the stars, but she knew exactly where to look. At 9:47 PM, a streak of light raced across the sky — the comet her grandfather had told her about.

What can you infer about Elena's grandfather?
choices: He shared his knowledge of astronomy with Elena
He has never seen a comet
questions.correct: He shared his knowledge of astronomy with Elena
questions.hint: Elena knew exactly where to look because her grandfather told her about the comet.

questions.prompt:
The letter had been folded and refolded so many times that the creases were soft as fabric. Marcus kept it in his front pocket, close to his chest, even though he'd memorized every word.

What can you infer about how Marcus feels about the letter?
choices: He wants to throw it away
It's extremely important and meaningful to him
questions.correct: It's extremely important and meaningful to him
questions.hint: He keeps it close to his chest and has memorized every word — those are signs of deep attachment.

questions.prompt:
Priya practiced her free throws every morning before school and every evening after dinner. On the day of tryouts, she was the only one who made all ten shots.

What detail from the text BEST supports the idea that hard work pays off?
choices: She practiced before school and after dinner
questions.correct: She practiced before school and after dinner
questions.hint: The detail about her practice schedule directly explains why she succeeded at tryouts.

questions.prompt:
Dad hadn't said a word during the entire drive home. He gripped the steering wheel tightly, and his jaw was clenched. When they pulled into the driveway, he finally sighed and said, 'We'll talk about this inside.'

What can you infer about Dad's mood?
choices: He's upset or frustrated about something
questions.correct: He's upset or frustrated about something
questions.hint: Silent, tight grip, clenched jaw, deep sigh — those are all signs of frustration.

questions.prompt:
The old bookshop smelled of leather and dust. Mrs. Tanaka knew every book by heart — where it sat, what it was about, who had loved it last. When the city announced the building would be torn down, she simply said, 'Books always find a new home.'

What does Mrs. Tanaka's response reveal about her character?
choices: She's optimistic and resilient even in difficult times
She doesn't care about the bookshop
questions.correct: She's optimistic and resilient even in difficult times
questions.hint: Instead of being devastated, she focuses on the positive — books will survive. That's resilience.

standards.standard_description: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'What big life lesson does this story teach?' — that's the theme.

questions.prompt:
Kai wanted to win the science fair more than anything. He worked alone, refusing help from his classmates. His project looked impressive but had a major flaw he hadn't noticed. Meanwhile, the team next to him — who had shared ideas and caught each other's mistakes — won first place.

What is the theme?
choices: Collaboration leads to better results than working alone
questions.correct: Collaboration leads to better results than working alone
questions.hint: Compare what happened to Kai (alone, missed a flaw) vs. the team (shared ideas, won).

questions.prompt:
Amara was embarrassed by her grandmother's accent and old-fashioned clothes. She asked Grandma not to come to the school play. After the show, Amara saw her classmates laughing with their grandparents and felt a deep ache. She called Grandma that night and said, 'Next time, front row.'

What is the theme?
choices: Don't be ashamed of your family — appreciate them
questions.correct: Don't be ashamed of your family — appreciate them
questions.hint: Amara regretted pushing her grandmother away and realized family matters more than appearances.

questions.prompt: A theme is different from a topic because —
choices: A theme is always stated directly
A theme is one word like 'friendship'
A theme is the message or lesson, while a topic is just the subject
questions.correct: A theme is the message or lesson, while a topic is just the subject
questions.hint: Topic = friendship. Theme = true friends stand by you in hard times.

questions.prompt:
The tiny seed was carried by the wind past tall trees and mighty oaks. It landed in a crack between two rocks where nothing grew. But the seed pushed through anyway, and years later it became the only tree on that rocky hill.

What is the theme?
choices: Determination can help you thrive even in difficult conditions
questions.correct: Determination can help you thrive even in difficult conditions
questions.hint: The seed grew where 'nothing grew' — it succeeded against the odds through persistence.

questions.prompt: Which is the BEST summary of a story?
choices: A copy of the first paragraph
A brief retelling of the main character, problem, key events, and resolution
A list of every single event that happened
questions.correct: A brief retelling of the main character, problem, key events, and resolution
questions.hint: A good summary hits the highlights: who, what problem, what happened, how it ended.

standards.standard_description: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child to describe characters using evidence: 'What did they say or do that shows that trait?'

questions.prompt:
Coach Reyes never raised her voice. When a player made a mistake, she'd kneel down, look them in the eye, and say, 'Tell me what you were thinking.' By season's end, every player said she was the best coach they'd ever had.

Which word BEST describes Coach Reyes?
questions.correct: Respectful
questions.hint: She kneels down, makes eye contact, and asks for their perspective — that's deep respect.

questions.prompt:
The marketplace buzzed with voices in a dozen languages. Spices piled in colorful mountains — saffron yellow, paprika red, turmeric orange. Somewhere a radio played scratchy music, and the smell of roasting lamb drifted through the narrow aisles.

The author uses these details to create a setting that feels —
choices: Vibrant, busy, and full of sensory experiences
questions.correct: Vibrant, busy, and full of sensory experiences
questions.hint: Voices, colors, music, smells — the author hits sight, sound, and smell to bring it alive.

questions.prompt:
Jordan's hands trembled as he opened the envelope. His eyes scanned the page, then widened. He read it again. Then a third time. Then he let out a whoop so loud the neighbors' dog started barking.

What can you infer about the letter's contents?
questions.correct: Very good news
questions.hint: Trembling hands (nervous), then widened eyes and a whoop (excitement) — that's great news!

questions.prompt: When describing a character 'in depth,' you should include —
choices: Their traits, motivations, thoughts, words, and actions
Only what other characters say about them
questions.correct: Their traits, motivations, thoughts, words, and actions
questions.hint: A deep character description goes beyond appearance — it explores WHO they are inside.

questions.prompt:
The abandoned lighthouse stood at the edge of the cliff, its paint peeling like sunburned skin. Waves crashed against the rocks below, sending spray twenty feet into the air. Inside, the spiral staircase groaned under the weight of years.

The setting creates a mood that is —
questions.correct: Eerie and isolated
questions.hint: Abandoned, peeling paint, crashing waves, groaning staircase — all create a lonely, spooky mood.

standards.standard_description: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event, drawing on specific details in the text.

standards.parent_tip: Discuss how authors use words creatively — 'What does the author really mean by that phrase?'

questions.prompt:
She had the Midas touch — every business she started turned into gold.

This allusion to King Midas means —
choices: She literally turned things to gold
questions.correct: Everything she did became successful
questions.hint: King Midas turned everything to gold. This phrase means everything she touches succeeds.

questions.prompt:
Cleaning out the garage was a Herculean task.

This allusion to Hercules means the task was —
choices: Extremely difficult and required great effort
questions.correct: Extremely difficult and required great effort
questions.hint: Hercules was famous for completing incredibly difficult tasks (his twelve labors).

questions.prompt:
The morning light tiptoed through the curtains.

What does 'tiptoed' suggest about the light?
choices: It was very bright and harsh
questions.correct: It entered gently and softly
questions.hint: Tiptoeing is quiet and careful — the light came in softly, not harshly.

questions.prompt:
His Achilles' heel was his temper — it always got him into trouble.

An 'Achilles' heel' refers to —
choices: A person's greatest weakness or vulnerability
questions.correct: A person's greatest weakness or vulnerability
questions.hint: In mythology, Achilles was invincible except for his heel. The phrase means a fatal weakness.

questions.prompt:
The silence in the library was so thick you could cut it with a knife.

This phrase means —
choices: People were cooking in the library
Someone had a knife in the library
The silence was intense and heavy
questions.correct: The silence was intense and heavy
questions.hint: This is figurative — the silence felt so strong and present it was almost physical.

standards.standard_description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology.

standards.parent_tip: Compare how the same story might look as a poem, a play, and a chapter book.

questions.prompt: Which structural element is found in a drama (play) but NOT in prose (a regular story)?
questions.correct: Stage directions
questions.hint: Stage directions (in italics or brackets) tell actors how to move and speak — only plays have these.

questions.prompt: A poem is organized into stanzas. Stanzas are similar to ____ in prose.
questions.correct: Paragraphs
questions.hint: Stanzas group lines in a poem, just like paragraphs group sentences in prose.

questions.prompt: How is dialogue presented differently in a play versus a novel?
choices: In plays, the character's name appears before their lines; novels use quotation marks
questions.correct: In plays, the character's name appears before their lines; novels use quotation marks
questions.hint: Play: ROMEO: But soft! Novel: "But soft!" said Romeo.

questions.prompt: What structural element do poems often have that prose does not?
questions.correct: Meter and rhyme scheme
questions.hint: Poems often have rhythm (meter) and patterns of rhyming — prose usually doesn't.

questions.prompt: A verse in a poem is most similar to a ____ in a novel.
questions.correct: Line or sentence
questions.hint: A verse is a single line of poetry — similar to how a sentence is a unit in prose.

standards.standard_description: Explain major differences between poems, drama, and prose; refer to structural elements when writing or speaking about a text.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'Is the character telling the story (first person) or is someone else describing it (third person)?'

questions.prompt:
I couldn't believe my eyes when I opened the door.

This is written in —
questions.correct: First person
questions.hint: The word 'I' is the key clue — the narrator is telling their own story.

questions.prompt:
Sarah couldn't believe her eyes when she opened the door.

This is written in —
questions.correct: Third person
questions.hint: The narrator uses 'she' and 'Sarah' — someone else is telling Sarah's story.

questions.prompt: How does first-person narration affect a story compared to third-person?
choices: Third person is always more honest
First person gives you access to every character's thoughts
First person limits you to one character's perspective and feelings
questions.correct: First person limits you to one character's perspective and feelings
questions.hint: With 'I,' you only know what THAT character knows and feels.

questions.prompt: A story told by an outside narrator who knows the thoughts and feelings of ALL characters is called —
questions.correct: Third person omniscient
questions.hint: 'Omniscient' means all-knowing — this narrator can see into everyone's mind.

questions.prompt:
The same event is described two ways: Version A: 'I scored the winning goal and felt like a hero.' Version B: 'Jake scored the winning goal. His teammates cheered, but the other team walked away in silence.'

How does the point of view change what the reader learns?
choices: Version A shows Jake's feelings; Version B shows both teams' reactions
Both versions give the same information
questions.correct: Version A shows Jake's feelings; Version B shows both teams' reactions
questions.hint: First person (A) gives inner feelings. Third person (B) gives a wider view of the scene.

standards.standard_description: Compare and contrast the point of view from which different stories are narrated, including first- and third-person.

standards.parent_tip: After reading a book, watch the movie version and discuss what's different and why.

questions.prompt: A student reads a chapter about a thunderstorm, then watches a movie version with dramatic music and dark lighting. The movie version adds —
choices: Mood and atmosphere through sound and visuals
questions.correct: Mood and atmosphere through sound and visuals
questions.hint: Music and lighting create feelings that words alone describe differently.

questions.prompt: When a book is turned into a play, what might be LOST?
choices: The character's inner thoughts described by the narrator
questions.correct: The character's inner thoughts described by the narrator
questions.hint: On stage, you can't hear what a character is thinking the way a narrator can tell you.

questions.prompt: What might a visual presentation (movie or play) ADD to a story that the text cannot?
choices: Facial expressions, tone of voice, and body language of actors
questions.correct: Facial expressions, tone of voice, and body language of actors
questions.hint: Actors bring characters to life with their faces, voices, and movements.

questions.prompt: A book describes a character as 'a tall woman with kind eyes.' In the movie, the actress has a warm smile and speaks softly. How does the movie expand on the text?
choices: It shows specific visual and audio details that bring 'kind eyes' to life
questions.correct: It shows specific visual and audio details that bring 'kind eyes' to life
questions.hint: The movie translates 'kind eyes' into a warm smile and soft voice — making it real.

questions.prompt: Why might a reader prefer the book version over the movie?
choices: The reader's imagination creates a personal version of the story
questions.correct: The reader's imagination creates a personal version of the story
questions.hint: When you read, YOU decide what characters look like and how settings feel.

standards.standard_description: Make connections between the text of a story or drama and a visual or oral presentation of the text.

standards.parent_tip: Read myths from different cultures and discuss: 'How does this culture explain the same thing differently?'

questions.prompt: A Greek myth says the sun is pulled across the sky by the god Helios in a chariot. A Native American story says the sun is carried by a spirit eagle. Both stories try to explain —
choices: How the sun moves across the sky
questions.correct: How the sun moves across the sky
questions.hint: Both cultures created stories to explain the same natural phenomenon — the sun's movement.

questions.prompt: Many cultures have flood myths — a great flood that covers the earth. What does this SIMILARITY suggest?
choices: They all copied from one story
Only one culture had a flood
Ancient peoples around the world may have experienced similar natural disasters
questions.correct: Ancient peoples around the world may have experienced similar natural disasters
questions.hint: When many cultures tell similar stories, it often reflects shared human experiences.

questions.prompt: A European fairy tale and a West African folktale both feature a clever trickster who outsmarts a more powerful character. The European version uses a fox; the African version uses a spider named Anansi. What is the SAME?
choices: The theme of cleverness defeating power
questions.correct: The theme of cleverness defeating power
questions.hint: Different characters, same message — brains can beat brawn.

questions.prompt: Why do different cultures often tell stories with similar themes?
choices: Human experiences like love, courage, and fairness are universal
They all speak the same language
They don't have any different themes
One culture wrote all the stories
questions.correct: Human experiences like love, courage, and fairness are universal
questions.hint: People everywhere face similar challenges and value similar things.

questions.prompt: When comparing myths from different cultures, the MOST important thing to examine is —
choices: How each culture uses its own characters and settings to explore universal themes
questions.correct: How each culture uses its own characters and settings to explore universal themes
questions.hint: The richest comparison looks at how different cultures express the same big ideas.

standards.standard_description: Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes and topics in stories, myths, and traditional literature from different cultures.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to read chapter books independently and discuss what they've read.

questions.prompt:
Nobody knew where the music came from. Every night at midnight, a violin played from somewhere deep in the woods. The townspeople locked their doors and whispered about ghosts. Only young Alma grabbed her lantern and followed the sound.

What does Alma's action reveal about her?
choices: She's curious and braver than the other townspeople
questions.correct: She's curious and braver than the other townspeople
questions.hint: While everyone else locked their doors in fear, Alma went TOWARD the mystery.

questions.prompt:
The treaty was signed on a Tuesday. By Wednesday, the two kingdoms had already broken it. 'Peace,' the old queen muttered, 'is harder to keep than to promise.'

What is the queen's message about peace?
choices: Making peace is simple but maintaining it is the real challenge
questions.correct: Making peace is simple but maintaining it is the real challenge
questions.hint: They signed peace easily but broke it immediately — keeping peace is the hard part.

questions.prompt:
Theo didn't notice the first leaf fall. Or the second. But by the time the maple tree was half bare, he understood what his grandmother meant when she said, 'Change happens slowly, then all at once.'

What is Grandmother's saying about?
choices: How change in life can be gradual then suddenly obvious
questions.correct: How change in life can be gradual then suddenly obvious
questions.hint: The leaves are a metaphor — change builds quietly until suddenly you notice everything is different.

questions.prompt:
Zuri had two rules: never break a promise, and always carry a pencil. 'You never know,' she said, 'when you'll need to write something down before you forget it — or before someone tries to make you forget.'

What does the second rule suggest about Zuri?
choices: She values truth and recording important things
questions.correct: She values truth and recording important things
questions.hint: She writes things down so they can't be changed or forgotten — she values accuracy and truth.

questions.prompt:
The ship had been at sea for thirty-seven days. Fresh water was running low, and the crew whispered about turning back. Captain Adaeze stood at the bow, eyes fixed on the horizon. 'Land by sunrise,' she said. Nobody believed her. But at dawn, there it was.

What theme does this passage suggest?
choices: Faith and determination can lead you through doubt
questions.correct: Faith and determination can lead you through doubt
questions.hint: Everyone doubted, but the captain held firm — and she was right.

standards.standard_description: By end of the year, read and comprehend literature in the grades 4-5 text complexity band proficiently.

standards.parent_tip: Teach your child to say 'The text says...' when supporting their answers with evidence.

questions.prompt:
The International Space Station orbits Earth at approximately 17,500 miles per hour. At this speed, astronauts experience 16 sunrises and 16 sunsets every 24 hours.

What detail explains why astronauts see so many sunrises?
choices: It orbits at 17,500 mph, completing an orbit roughly every 90 minutes
The sun moves faster in space
questions.correct: It orbits at 17,500 mph, completing an orbit roughly every 90 minutes
questions.hint: The extreme speed means it circles Earth many times a day — each orbit brings a new sunrise.

questions.prompt:
Jane Goodall arrived in Tanzania in 1960 with no formal training in science. Within months, she observed chimpanzees using sticks as tools to extract termites — a discovery that changed our understanding of what makes humans unique.

What inference can you make about why this discovery was so important?
choices: Scientists previously believed only humans used tools
People didn't know about termites before
questions.correct: Scientists previously believed only humans used tools
questions.hint: The text says it 'changed our understanding of what makes humans unique' — tool use was thought to be a human-only ability.

questions.prompt:
Honeybees communicate through a 'waggle dance.' A bee returning from a food source dances in a figure-eight pattern. The angle of the dance indicates the direction of the food relative to the sun.

What specific detail tells you HOW bees show direction?
choices: They fly in a straight line
The angle of the dance relative to the sun
questions.correct: The angle of the dance relative to the sun
questions.hint: The last sentence gives the precise detail about direction.

questions.prompt:
During the California Gold Rush of 1849, most miners didn't get rich from gold. However, merchants who sold pickaxes, shovels, and jeans to the miners made fortunes.

What can you infer from this passage?
choices: Selling supplies to miners was more profitable than mining itself
The Gold Rush lasted one year
questions.correct: Selling supplies to miners was more profitable than mining itself
questions.hint: Most miners didn't get rich, but the people selling them tools did — what does that tell you?

questions.prompt: When you 'draw an inference' from a text, you —
choices: Copy a sentence from the text
Draw a picture of the text
Use clues from the text plus your own knowledge to figure something out
questions.correct: Use clues from the text plus your own knowledge to figure something out
questions.hint: An inference = text evidence + your brain. You figure out what the author implies but doesn't directly say.

standards.standard_description: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences.

standards.parent_tip: Practice: 'What's the ONE big idea? Now give me three details that prove it.'

questions.prompt:
Plastic pollution is devastating ocean ecosystems. Over 8 million tons of plastic enter the oceans each year. Sea turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish. Microplastics have been found in fish that humans eat.

What is the main idea?
choices: Plastic pollution is seriously harming ocean life
questions.correct: Plastic pollution is seriously harming ocean life
questions.hint: The first sentence states the main idea. Every other sentence supports it with examples.

questions.prompt:
Ancient Rome's road system was an engineering marvel. Roman roads were built in layers — gravel, sand, and paving stones — designed to last centuries. Over 250,000 miles of roads connected the empire. Many of these roads are still visible today.

Which detail BEST supports the main idea that Roman roads were remarkable?
choices: Many roads are still visible centuries later
questions.correct: Many roads are still visible centuries later
questions.hint: Roads lasting CENTURIES is the most powerful evidence of their remarkable quality.

questions.prompt: A good summary of an informational text includes —
choices: The main idea and the most important supporting details in your own words
Every single detail from the text
questions.correct: The main idea and the most important supporting details in your own words
questions.hint: Summaries are brief — main idea + key details, in YOUR words, no small details.

questions.prompt:
Exercise benefits the brain in multiple ways. Physical activity increases blood flow to the brain, delivering more oxygen. It also triggers the release of chemicals that improve mood and focus. Studies show students who exercise regularly perform better academically.

How does the detail about students support the main idea?
choices: It provides real-world evidence that exercise helps brains work better
questions.correct: It provides real-world evidence that exercise helps brains work better
questions.hint: Better academic performance = proof that exercise benefits the brain. It's concrete evidence!

questions.prompt:
Paragraph 1: Renewable energy sources like solar and wind are growing rapidly. Paragraph 2: Solar panel costs have dropped 89% since 2010. Paragraph 3: Wind energy now powers millions of homes.

The main idea of the ENTIRE passage is —
choices: Renewable energy is growing and becoming more accessible
questions.correct: Renewable energy is growing and becoming more accessible
questions.hint: Both paragraphs 2 and 3 give specific examples supporting the big idea in paragraph 1.

standards.standard_description: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child to explain what happened and WHY — 'What caused that? What was the result?'

questions.prompt:
In 1773, American colonists were furious about being taxed by Britain without representation in Parliament. A group of colonists disguised as Native Americans boarded British ships and dumped 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor.

What caused the Boston Tea Party?
choices: The ships were blocking the harbor
questions.correct: Anger over taxation without representation
questions.hint: The first sentence states the cause — being taxed without having a voice in government.

questions.prompt:
Vaccines work by introducing a weakened or inactive form of a virus to the body. The immune system learns to recognize and fight the virus. If the person is later exposed to the real virus, their body already knows how to defeat it.

Explain the SEQUENCE of how vaccines work:
choices: Real virus enters → immune system fights → vaccine given
Vaccine introduces weak virus → immune system learns to fight it → body is prepared for the real virus
Body gets sick → takes medicine → feels better
Immune system attacks → virus enters → vaccine helps
questions.correct: Vaccine introduces weak virus → immune system learns to fight it → body is prepared for the real virus
questions.hint: Follow the order: introduce weak virus first, then the body learns, then it's ready.

questions.prompt:
The invention of the printing press in 1440 made books affordable for the first time. Before that, books were copied by hand, making them rare and expensive. As books became accessible, literacy rates soared across Europe.

What was the EFFECT of the printing press on literacy?
choices: Literacy rates soared because books became accessible
questions.correct: Literacy rates soared because books became accessible
questions.hint: Affordable books → more people could get books → more people learned to read.

questions.prompt:
Photosynthesis occurs in the leaves of plants. Chlorophyll in the leaves absorbs sunlight. The plant combines this energy with water from the roots and carbon dioxide from the air to produce glucose and oxygen.

What are the INPUTS (ingredients) of photosynthesis?
questions.correct: Sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide
questions.hint: The plant combines sunlight + water + CO2 to MAKE glucose and oxygen.

questions.prompt: When explaining a historical event, it's important to include —
choices: What happened, why it happened, and what resulted from it
questions.correct: What happened, why it happened, and what resulted from it
questions.hint: A complete explanation covers the event, its causes, and its effects.

standards.standard_description: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text.

standards.parent_tip: Help your child use context clues, word parts, and reference tools together to unlock tough vocabulary.

questions.prompt:
The archaeologist carefully excavated the site, removing layers of dirt to reveal ancient pottery buried for thousands of years.

What does 'excavated' mean?
questions.correct: Dug up carefully
questions.hint: She's removing layers of dirt to reveal things — that's careful digging.

questions.prompt:
The legislative branch of government is responsible for making laws. Congress, made up of the Senate and House of Representatives, is the legislative branch.

What does 'legislative' relate to?
questions.correct: Making laws
questions.hint: The text defines it directly — the legislative branch MAKES laws.

questions.prompt:
The ecosystem was thriving — diverse species of plants and animals coexisted in a balanced, interdependent community.

What does 'interdependent' mean?
questions.correct: Depending on each other
questions.hint: 'Inter' means between/among. 'Dependent' means relying on. Together = relying on each other.

questions.prompt:
The metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a butterfly involves a complete transformation of the insect's body.

What does 'metamorphosis' mean?
questions.correct: A dramatic change in form
questions.hint: The text says 'complete transformation' right after — that defines metamorphosis!

questions.prompt:
The drought caused widespread famine. Crops withered in the fields, and livestock had no grass to eat. Thousands of people faced severe hunger.

What does 'famine' mean?
questions.correct: Extreme widespread hunger
questions.hint: Crops died, animals starved, thousands faced severe hunger — famine means extreme hunger on a large scale.

standards.standard_description: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text.

standards.parent_tip: Help your child identify text structures: is the author comparing, showing cause/effect, describing a sequence, or presenting a problem and solution?

questions.prompt: A passage first describes a problem (too much trash in the ocean) and then explains ways to fix it (recycling programs, beach cleanups). This text structure is —
questions.correct: Problem and solution
questions.hint: Problem presented → solution offered. Classic problem/solution structure!

questions.prompt: Signal words like 'first, next, then, finally' indicate which text structure?
questions.correct: Chronological/sequential order
questions.hint: These words show ORDER — things happening in sequence.

questions.prompt: A passage about hurricanes and tornadoes uses words like 'similarly,' 'however,' and 'on the other hand.' This structure is —
questions.correct: Compare and contrast
questions.hint: 'Similarly' shows likeness; 'however' and 'on the other hand' show differences.

questions.prompt:
Because the temperature dropped below freezing, the pipes burst. As a result, the basement flooded.

This is an example of —
questions.correct: Cause and effect
questions.hint: 'Because' and 'as a result' are cause-and-effect signal words.

questions.prompt: Why is it helpful to identify a text's structure?
choices: It helps you understand how the author organized ideas and find information more easily
It changes the meaning of the text
questions.correct: It helps you understand how the author organized ideas and find information more easily
questions.hint: Knowing the structure is like having a map — it helps you navigate the text.

standards.standard_description: Describe the overall structure of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text.

standards.parent_tip: Discuss: 'A diary entry is firsthand (I was there). A textbook is secondhand (someone describes what happened).'

questions.prompt: A firsthand account is written by someone who —
choices: Heard about it from a friend
Was actually there and experienced it
Read about the event in a book
questions.correct: Was actually there and experienced it
questions.hint: Firsthand = first person = 'I was there.'

questions.prompt: Which is a firsthand account?
choices: A soldier's diary from the Civil War battlefield
A textbook chapter about the Civil War
A Wikipedia article about a battle
questions.correct: A soldier's diary from the Civil War battlefield
questions.hint: The soldier was THERE. Everyone else is writing about it secondhand.

questions.prompt: How might a firsthand account DIFFER from a secondhand account of the same event?
choices: Firsthand accounts include personal feelings and experiences; secondhand accounts are more objective
questions.correct: Firsthand accounts include personal feelings and experiences; secondhand accounts are more objective
questions.hint: Being there means emotions and personal details. Writing about it later means more distance and objectivity.

questions.prompt:
Account A: 'I could feel the ground shaking under my feet. Dust filled the air and I couldn't see.' Account B: 'The earthquake measured 6.7 on the Richter scale and caused significant structural damage.'

Which is firsthand?
questions.correct: Account A
questions.hint: Account A uses 'I' and describes personal sensory experiences. That's firsthand!

questions.prompt: Why is it valuable to read BOTH firsthand and secondhand accounts?
choices: Firsthand gives personal perspective; secondhand gives broader context — together you get a fuller picture
questions.correct: Firsthand gives personal perspective; secondhand gives broader context — together you get a fuller picture
questions.hint: Each type offers something the other can't. Together, they give you the complete story.

standards.standard_description: Compare and contrast a firsthand and secondhand account of the same event or topic.

standards.parent_tip: Practice reading charts, graphs, and timelines — ask your child what story the data tells.

questions.prompt: A bar graph shows that the school recycled 200 pounds in January, 350 in February, and 500 in March. What trend does the graph show?
questions.correct: Recycling increased each month
questions.hint: 200 → 350 → 500. The numbers are going UP each month.

questions.prompt: A timeline in a history text shows events from 1760 to 1790. This visual helps readers —
choices: Understand the exact words people said
See the sequence and spacing of events over time
questions.correct: See the sequence and spacing of events over time
questions.hint: Timelines show WHEN things happened and how much time passed between events.

questions.prompt: A pie chart shows: 45% of students prefer pizza, 30% prefer tacos, 15% prefer pasta, 10% prefer salad. What can you conclude?
choices: Tacos and pizza are equally popular
Pizza is the most popular but not everyone's favorite
questions.correct: Pizza is the most popular but not everyone's favorite
questions.hint: 45% is the biggest slice, but that means 55% prefer something else!

questions.prompt: How does a diagram of the human digestive system help a reader MORE than a written description alone?
choices: It adds color to the page
It shows the physical layout and connections between organs that are hard to describe in words
It replaces the need to read
questions.correct: It shows the physical layout and connections between organs that are hard to describe in words
questions.hint: Seeing WHERE organs are and how they connect is much easier in a picture than in words.

questions.prompt: When interpreting a graph, the FIRST thing you should look at is —
choices: The title and axis labels to understand what data is being shown
questions.correct: The title and axis labels to understand what data is being shown
questions.hint: Before reading the data, you need to know WHAT the graph is measuring!

standards.standard_description: Interpret information presented visually, orally, or quantitatively and explain how it contributes to understanding.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'What point is the author making? What evidence do they give to back it up?'

questions.prompt:
Schools should offer more art classes. Studies show that students in art programs score higher on standardized tests. Art also teaches creativity, problem-solving, and collaboration.

The author supports their point with —
choices: Research studies and specific skills art teaches
questions.correct: Research studies and specific skills art teaches
questions.hint: The author uses data (test scores) AND specific benefits (creativity, problem-solving) as evidence.

questions.prompt: Which type of evidence is STRONGEST?
choices: 'Studies show students who have recess perform 20% better on afternoon tests'
questions.correct: 'Studies show students who have recess perform 20% better on afternoon tests'
questions.hint: Specific data from studies is stronger than opinions or vague claims.

questions.prompt:
Endangered species need stronger legal protections. The bald eagle was nearly extinct until the Endangered Species Act helped its population recover from 417 pairs in 1963 to over 316,000 today.

How does the bald eagle example support the author's point?
choices: It changes the topic to birds
It proves that legal protections actually work to save species
questions.correct: It proves that legal protections actually work to save species
questions.hint: The author's point is that protections are needed. The eagle example PROVES they work.

questions.prompt: When evaluating an author's argument, you should ask —
choices: Does the evidence actually support the point being made?
questions.correct: Does the evidence actually support the point being made?
questions.hint: Critical readers check whether the evidence truly connects to and proves the author's claim.

questions.prompt: An author argues that school lunches should be healthier. Which evidence would NOT support this point?
choices: Students who eat nutritious lunches concentrate better
Processed foods are linked to health problems
The cafeteria was painted blue last year
questions.correct: The cafeteria was painted blue last year
questions.hint: The paint color has nothing to do with how healthy the food is — it's irrelevant evidence.

standards.standard_description: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.

standards.parent_tip: Read two articles on the same topic and help your child combine what they learned from both.

questions.prompt: Text A explains how solar panels convert sunlight to electricity. Text B discusses the environmental benefits of solar energy. To write a complete report on solar energy, you should —
choices: Ignore both and use your own knowledge
questions.correct: Combine information from both texts
questions.hint: Each text contributes different pieces. Together, they give you a complete picture.

questions.prompt:
Text A: 'Mars has a thin atmosphere made mostly of carbon dioxide.' Text B: 'Mars has massive dust storms that can cover the entire planet for months.'

Using both texts, what can you explain about Mars?
choices: Both its atmospheric composition AND its extreme weather patterns
questions.correct: Both its atmospheric composition AND its extreme weather patterns
questions.hint: Text A gives atmosphere facts. Text B gives weather facts. Together = a fuller picture of Mars.

questions.prompt: When integrating information from two sources, what should you watch for?
choices: Whether the sources agree, disagree, or provide complementary information
questions.correct: Whether the sources agree, disagree, or provide complementary information
questions.hint: Good researchers note when sources support each other, contradict each other, or fill in different gaps.

questions.prompt: Text A says wolves were removed from Yellowstone in the 1920s. Text B says after wolves were reintroduced in 1995, the elk population became healthier and rivers changed course. Combining these texts helps you understand —
choices: The long-term impact of removing and then restoring a species to an ecosystem
questions.correct: The long-term impact of removing and then restoring a species to an ecosystem
questions.hint: Text A = removal. Text B = reintroduction and effects. Together = the full cause-and-effect story.

questions.prompt: Why is using multiple sources better than using just one?
choices: Multiple sources provide different perspectives, details, and a more complete understanding
You should always use exactly one source
More sources means a longer report
questions.correct: Multiple sources provide different perspectives, details, and a more complete understanding
questions.hint: Each source might cover different angles or details. Together, your understanding is richer.

standards.standard_description: Integrate information from two texts on the same topic to write or speak about the subject knowledgeably.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage reading nonfiction books, articles, and magazines about topics your child is passionate about.

questions.prompt:
The human brain weighs about three pounds but uses roughly 20% of the body's total energy. It contains approximately 86 billion neurons, each connected to thousands of others, forming a network more complex than any computer ever built.

What comparison does the author make to emphasize the brain's complexity?
questions.correct: Comparing it to a computer
questions.hint: The author says the brain's network is 'more complex than any computer ever built.'

questions.prompt:
The Dead Sea, located between Israel and Jordan, is nearly ten times saltier than the ocean. This extreme salinity means no fish or plants can survive in it — hence the name. However, the mineral-rich mud and water have been used for health treatments for thousands of years.

What is ironic about the Dead Sea?
choices: Despite being called 'dead,' it has been valuable for human health for millennia
questions.correct: Despite being called 'dead,' it has been valuable for human health for millennia
questions.hint: Called 'dead' because nothing lives in it — yet it HELPS living humans. That's ironic!

questions.prompt:
In 1983, Dr. Sally Ride became the first American woman in space. She later founded Sally Ride Science, an organization encouraging girls to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and math.

What does this tell you about Dr. Ride's priorities?
choices: She only cared about her own career
She wanted to inspire the next generation, especially girls, to follow in her footsteps
questions.correct: She wanted to inspire the next generation, especially girls, to follow in her footsteps
questions.hint: She founded an organization specifically to encourage girls in STEM — that shows her priorities.

questions.prompt:
Bamboo is one of the fastest-growing plants on Earth, capable of growing up to 35 inches in a single day. It's also incredibly strong — pound for pound, bamboo has a greater tensile strength than steel.

Why might bamboo be considered a 'super-plant'?
choices: It grows extremely fast AND is stronger than steel by weight
questions.correct: It grows extremely fast AND is stronger than steel by weight
questions.hint: Two extraordinary qualities: incredible growth speed AND incredible strength.

questions.prompt:
The Library of Alexandria, built around 300 BCE in Egypt, was the ancient world's greatest center of learning. Scholars from across the Mediterranean came to study its estimated 400,000 scrolls. When it was eventually destroyed, countless works of ancient knowledge were lost forever.

What makes the Library's destruction significant?
choices: Irreplaceable knowledge accumulated over centuries was permanently lost
questions.correct: Irreplaceable knowledge accumulated over centuries was permanently lost
questions.hint: 400,000 scrolls of ancient knowledge — gone forever. That's a massive loss to human history.

standards.standard_description: By end of year, read and comprehend informational texts in the grades 4-5 text complexity band proficiently.

standards.parent_tip: Help your child use roots, prefixes, and suffixes to decode unfamiliar multisyllabic words.

questions.prompt: The word 'autobiography' can be broken into: auto + bio + graph + y. Using these parts, what does it mean?
choices: A life story written by the person themselves
questions.correct: A life story written by the person themselves
questions.hint: Auto = self, bio = life, graph = write. Self + life + write = writing about your own life!

questions.prompt: Which word contains the Greek root 'tele' meaning 'far'?
questions.correct: All of the above
questions.hint: Tele = far. Phone = sound. Vision = seeing. Scope = viewing. All involve far-distance!

questions.prompt: How many syllables are in the word 'communication'?
questions.hint: Clap it: com-mu-ni-ca-tion. Five beats!

questions.prompt: In the word 'unbreakable,' the prefix, root, and suffix are —
questions.correct: Un + break + able
questions.hint: Un- (not) + break (root) + -able (can be done) = cannot be broken.

questions.prompt: The word 'pseudonym' uses the Greek root 'pseudo' meaning 'false' and 'nym' meaning 'name.' A pseudonym is —
choices: A false or fake name used by an author
questions.correct: A false or fake name used by an author
questions.hint: False + name = a fake name. Authors like Mark Twain used pseudonyms!

standards.standard_description: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills in decoding words.

standards.parent_tip: When facing a big word, try: 1) Break into syllables, 2) Look for familiar roots/affixes, 3) Sound it out, 4) Check if it makes sense.

questions.prompt: You encounter the unfamiliar word 'transportation.' What's the BEST first step?
choices: Break it into parts: trans + port + a + tion
questions.correct: Break it into parts: trans + port + a + tion
questions.hint: Breaking big words into smaller, recognizable parts makes them manageable!

questions.prompt: The word 'international' can be decoded as —
questions.correct: In + ter + nation + al
questions.hint: Inter (between) + nation + al (relating to) = between nations.

questions.prompt: If you know that '-ology' means 'study of,' what does 'biology' study?
questions.correct: Living things (bio = life)
questions.hint: Bio = life. -ology = study of. Biology = study of life!

questions.prompt: How many syllables are in 'extraordinary'?
questions.hint: ex-tra-or-di-na-ry. Count each vowel sound!

questions.prompt: You see the word 'misconception' for the first time. Using morphology, what does it mean?
questions.correct: A wrong or mistaken belief
questions.hint: Mis (wrong) + concept (idea) + ion (state of) = a wrong idea or mistaken belief.

standards.standard_description: Use combined knowledge of letter-sound correspondences, syllabication patterns, and morphology to read accurately unfamiliar multisyllabic words.

standards.parent_tip: Have your child read aloud regularly — fluent reading should sound like natural conversation.

questions.prompt: A fluent reader adjusts their reading speed based on —
choices: The difficulty and type of text they're reading
questions.correct: The difficulty and type of text they're reading
questions.hint: You'd read a science textbook slower than a fun novel. Good readers adjust!

questions.prompt: Why is reading fluency important for comprehension?
choices: When you read smoothly, your brain can focus on understanding instead of struggling with words
Fluency only matters for reading aloud
questions.correct: When you read smoothly, your brain can focus on understanding instead of struggling with words
questions.hint: If you're stuck on every word, you can't focus on meaning. Fluency frees your brain to think.

questions.prompt: When reading a passage with technical vocabulary, a good reader should —
choices: Speed up to get through it faster
Slow down and use context clues to understand unfamiliar terms
questions.correct: Slow down and use context clues to understand unfamiliar terms
questions.hint: Hard vocabulary = slow down, not speed up. Use context to figure out the meaning.

questions.prompt: Which shows the BEST reading fluency?
choices: Skipping every other word to read faster
Reading... each... word... one... at... a... time...
Reading smoothly with natural pauses at commas and periods, and expression that matches the content
questions.correct: Reading smoothly with natural pauses at commas and periods, and expression that matches the content
questions.hint: Fluent reading flows naturally — not too choppy, not too rushed.

questions.prompt: Self-monitoring while reading means —
choices: Checking your own understanding as you read and going back when something doesn't make sense
Having someone else check your reading
questions.correct: Checking your own understanding as you read and going back when something doesn't make sense
questions.hint: Good readers constantly ask themselves 'Does this make sense?' as they read.

standards.standard_description: Read with sufficient accuracy and fluency to support comprehension.

standards.parent_tip: Teach your child multiple strategies: context clues, word parts, and dictionary skills — use them together.

questions.prompt:
The company decided to table the discussion until next week's meeting.

In this sentence, 'table' means —
questions.correct: To postpone or delay
questions.hint: 'Table the discussion until next week' — they're putting it aside for later.

questions.prompt:
After the long hike, the exhausted climbers sought refuge in a mountain cabin.

What does 'refuge' mean?
questions.correct: A safe place or shelter
questions.hint: They were exhausted and needed somewhere safe to rest — a shelter.

questions.prompt:
The word 'scale' has many meanings. What does it mean here?

"The fish's scale shimmered in the sunlight."
choices: A thin plate covering a fish's body
questions.correct: A thin plate covering a fish's body
questions.hint: Context: it's on a fish and it shimmers. That's the thin, shiny covering!

questions.prompt:
The philanthropist donated millions to build schools in underserved communities.

Using the Greek roots 'phil' (love) and 'anthrop' (human), a philanthropist is someone who —
choices: Loves helping humanity through generous donations
questions.correct: Loves helping humanity through generous donations
questions.hint: Phil = love + anthrop = human. A lover of humanity who helps through generosity!

questions.prompt: When you encounter a word with multiple meanings, the BEST way to determine which meaning is correct is —
choices: Use the surrounding context to figure out which meaning fits
Always use the first definition in the dictionary
questions.correct: Use the surrounding context to figure out which meaning fits
questions.hint: The words around a multiple-meaning word tell you which definition the author intended.

standards.standard_description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content.

standards.parent_tip: Model this strategy: 'I don't know this word, but the rest of the sentence tells me...'

questions.prompt:
The unprecedented snowstorm shut down the entire city — nothing like it had ever happened before.

What does 'unprecedented' mean?
questions.correct: Never happened before
questions.hint: The text literally says 'nothing like it had ever happened before' — that defines unprecedented!

questions.prompt:
The resilient community rebuilt their homes after the hurricane, stronger than before.

What does 'resilient' mean?
choices: Able to recover and bounce back
questions.correct: Able to recover and bounce back
questions.hint: They rebuilt stronger than before — that's bouncing back from difficulty!

questions.prompt:
Her meticulous notes included every detail — dates, names, page numbers, and color-coded tabs.

What does 'meticulous' mean?
questions.correct: Extremely careful and thorough
questions.hint: Every detail, color-coded tabs — that's extremely thorough and careful work!

questions.prompt:
The two countries formed an alliance, agreeing to protect each other in times of war.

An 'alliance' is —
choices: A partnership or agreement to work together
questions.correct: A partnership or agreement to work together
questions.hint: They agreed to protect EACH OTHER — that's a cooperative partnership.

questions.prompt:
The verbose speaker went on for two hours, using far more words than necessary to make simple points.

What does 'verbose' mean?
questions.correct: Using too many words
questions.hint: Two hours and 'far more words than necessary' — verbose means overly wordy!

standards.standard_description: Use context as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

standards.parent_tip: Learn root words together: graph = write, port = carry, rupt = break, dict = say.

questions.prompt: The Latin root 'dict' means 'to say or speak.' What does 'predict' mean?
choices: To say before — to tell what will happen in advance
questions.correct: To say before — to tell what will happen in advance
questions.hint: Pre (before) + dict (say) = say before it happens = predict!

questions.prompt: The Greek root 'graph' means 'to write.' Which word means 'a person's own handwriting of their name'?
questions.correct: Autograph
questions.hint: Auto (self) + graph (write) = self-writing = your own signature!

questions.prompt: The Latin root 'rupt' means 'to break.' What does 'interrupt' mean?
choices: To break into a conversation or process
questions.correct: To break into a conversation or process
questions.hint: Inter (between) + rupt (break) = break into the middle of something.

questions.prompt: The Greek prefix 'micro-' means 'small.' What does 'microscope' let you see?
questions.correct: Very small things
questions.hint: Micro (small) + scope (to view) = a tool for viewing small things!

questions.prompt: If 'bene-' means 'good' and 'mal-' means 'bad,' which word means 'a person who does good'?
questions.correct: Benefactor
questions.hint: Bene (good) + factor (doer) = a person who does good (like donating money).

standards.standard_description: Use common Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word.

standards.parent_tip: Teach your child to use online dictionaries, thesauruses, and pronunciation guides independently.

questions.prompt: A dictionary entry shows: 'ar·chi·pel·a·go (ar-kuh-PEL-uh-go) n. a group of islands.' What does the entry in parentheses tell you?
questions.correct: How to pronounce the word
questions.hint: The syllable breakdown and capitalized stress show you how to SAY the word.

questions.prompt: You want to find a word that means the same as 'happy' but with a stronger feeling. Which reference should you use?
questions.correct: A thesaurus
questions.hint: A thesaurus gives you synonyms — words with similar meanings but different intensities.

questions.prompt: In a dictionary, the abbreviation 'v.' means the word is a —
questions.correct: Verb
questions.hint: v. = verb, n. = noun, adj. = adjective. These tell you the part of speech.

questions.prompt: A dictionary shows three definitions for 'crane': 1. A large bird. 2. A machine for lifting heavy objects. 3. To stretch one's neck. The sentence is: 'She craned her neck to see over the crowd.' Which definition applies?
questions.correct: Definition 3
questions.hint: She stretched her neck to see — that matches definition 3!

questions.prompt: When should you consult a reference material instead of relying only on context clues?
choices: Never — context clues are always sufficient
When context clues aren't enough to determine the precise meaning
questions.correct: When context clues aren't enough to determine the precise meaning
questions.hint: Context clues are the first strategy, but sometimes you need the exact definition — that's when you grab a dictionary.

standards.standard_description: Consult reference materials to find the pronunciation and determine or clarify the precise meaning of key words.

standards.parent_tip: Explore figurative language in books, songs, and everyday conversation — similes, metaphors, idioms, and more.

questions.prompt:
The news hit her like a ton of bricks.

This is an example of —
questions.correct: A simile
questions.hint: The word 'like' compares the news to a ton of bricks. That's a simile!

questions.prompt:
The world is a stage, and we are merely players.

This is an example of —
questions.correct: A metaphor
questions.hint: It says the world IS a stage — direct comparison without 'like' or 'as.' That's a metaphor.

questions.prompt: What does the idiom 'hit the nail on the head' mean?
questions.correct: To be exactly right
questions.hint: If you hit a nail perfectly on its head, you got it exactly right!

questions.prompt:
The old car coughed and sputtered before finally dying on the side of the road.

This is an example of —
questions.correct: Personification
questions.hint: Cars can't cough, sputter, or die — those are human/living qualities given to a non-living thing.

questions.prompt: Which pair of words shows the GREATEST difference in intensity?
questions.correct: Upset and furious
questions.hint: Upset is mild. Furious is extreme. That's the biggest jump in intensity.

standards.standard_description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

standards.parent_tip: Ask 'What two things are being compared? What do they have in common?'

questions.prompt:
Her smile was as bright as the sun.

This simile compares —
choices: Her smile to sunlight — both are bright and warm
questions.correct: Her smile to sunlight — both are bright and warm
questions.hint: 'As bright as the sun' — her smile is being compared to the sun's brightness.

questions.prompt:
Time is money.

This metaphor means —
choices: Time is valuable and shouldn't be wasted, just like money
questions.correct: Time is valuable and shouldn't be wasted, just like money
questions.hint: The metaphor says time IS money — meaning time is just as valuable as money.

questions.prompt:
The dancer moved like water flowing over rocks.

What quality of the dancer does this simile highlight?
questions.correct: She moved smoothly and gracefully
questions.hint: Water flowing over rocks is smooth and graceful — that's how the dancer moved.

questions.prompt:
He has a heart of stone.

This metaphor means —
choices: He is cold, uncaring, and unfeeling
questions.correct: He is cold, uncaring, and unfeeling
questions.hint: Stone is hard and cold. A heart of stone = a person who doesn't show emotions or compassion.

questions.prompt: How do you tell the difference between a simile and a metaphor?
choices: Similes use 'like' or 'as'; metaphors make a direct comparison without them
questions.correct: Similes use 'like' or 'as'; metaphors make a direct comparison without them
questions.hint: Simile: 'brave AS a lion.' Metaphor: 'He IS a lion.' The words 'like/as' are the key difference.

standards.standard_description: Explain the meaning of simple similes and metaphors in context.

standards.parent_tip: Collect idioms as a family: 'Actions speak louder than words' — discuss what they really mean.

questions.prompt: What does the proverb 'Don't judge a book by its cover' mean?
choices: Don't evaluate things or people based only on appearance
questions.correct: Don't evaluate things or people based only on appearance
questions.hint: A book (or person) might look one way on the outside but be completely different inside.

questions.prompt: What does the adage 'Actions speak louder than words' mean?
choices: What you DO matters more than what you SAY
questions.correct: What you DO matters more than what you SAY
questions.hint: Anyone can SAY they'll help, but actually DOING it is what counts.

questions.prompt: What does the idiom 'costs an arm and a leg' mean?
choices: You have to lose body parts
questions.correct: Something is very expensive
questions.hint: You wouldn't literally give an arm and leg — this means the price is extremely high!

questions.prompt: What does the proverb 'The early bird catches the worm' teach?
choices: Worms are best in the morning
Those who act first or prepare early have an advantage
questions.correct: Those who act first or prepare early have an advantage
questions.hint: Being early and taking action gives you an advantage — in life, not just bird-feeding!

questions.prompt: What does 'When it rains, it pours' mean?
choices: When problems happen, they tend to come all at once
questions.correct: When problems happen, they tend to come all at once
questions.hint: It's not about weather — it means difficulties tend to pile up all at the same time.

standards.standard_description: Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs.

standards.parent_tip: Play synonym/antonym games: 'What's a fancier word for happy? What's the opposite of generous?'

questions.prompt: Which word is a SYNONYM for 'courageous'?
questions.correct: Brave
questions.hint: A synonym has a similar meaning. Courageous and brave both mean showing courage.

questions.prompt: Which word is an ANTONYM for 'generous'?
questions.correct: Selfish
questions.hint: An antonym is the opposite. The opposite of giving freely (generous) is keeping everything for yourself (selfish).

questions.prompt: The words 'happy,' 'joyful,' and 'ecstatic' are synonyms, but they differ in —
choices: Their intensity — from mild to extreme happiness
questions.correct: Their intensity — from mild to extreme happiness
questions.hint: Happy is mild. Joyful is stronger. Ecstatic is extreme. Same family, different levels.

questions.prompt:
Which word BEST replaces 'said' to show the character is angry?

"'That's not fair!' ____ Marcus."
questions.correct: Shouted
questions.hint: An angry person saying 'That's not fair!' would most likely raise their voice — shout!

questions.prompt: Which pair are antonyms?
questions.correct: Expand and contract
questions.hint: Expand = get bigger. Contract = get smaller. Those are opposites!

standards.standard_description: Demonstrate understanding of words by relating them to their opposites and to words with similar but not identical meanings.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to use precise, interesting vocabulary in their writing and conversations.

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses the most precise language?
choices: The rocket accelerated through the atmosphere at tremendous speed.
questions.correct: The rocket accelerated through the atmosphere at tremendous speed.
questions.hint: Precise means specific. 'Rocket,' 'accelerated,' 'atmosphere,' and 'tremendous' are all precise.

questions.prompt: In social studies, the word 'democracy' means —
choices: A system where citizens have the power to make decisions through voting
questions.correct: A system where citizens have the power to make decisions through voting
questions.hint: Demo = people. Cracy = rule. Democracy = rule by the people.

questions.prompt:
Replace 'nice' with a more precise word:

"The ____ sunset painted the sky in shades of orange and pink."
questions.correct: Spectacular
questions.hint: A sunset that paints the sky deserves a more vivid word than 'nice'!

questions.prompt: The academic phrase 'in contrast' signals that the author is about to —
questions.correct: Show a difference
questions.hint: 'In contrast' = the next idea will be different from the previous one.

questions.prompt: Which word BEST describes someone who stammered, looked at the floor, and spoke in a shaky voice?
questions.correct: Nervous
questions.hint: Stammering, avoiding eye contact, shaky voice — classic signs of nervousness!

standards.standard_description: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases.
